awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Modeling and Analytics for COVID-19 Outbreak Response in India: A multi-institutional, US-India joint collaborative effort
awd_abstract_narration:
This project includes study of three broad problems pertaining to pandemic science with a specific focus on the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak in India. Team members from U. Virginia, Princeton University, Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics & Policy, the Indian Institute of Science and the Indian Statistical Institute, Bengaluru will study three central problems: (i) biosurveillance, (ii) forecasting and (iii) vaccine allocation. The choice of tasks is based on current needs, the importance of the problem, and the likelihood that they can be solved in a timely fashion. 

The first topic is integrated active biosurveillance. During this pandemic the interplay between viral mutations, human behavior, vaccines, and public policies has been unprecedented. An integral element of managing such a pandemic is biosurveillance; this involves collecting samples, testing and sequencing viruses across space and time, and combining this information to assess the distribution and impact of the viral strains. This project will use an abductive framework for smart biosurveillance – budget constrained methods for testing, genomic sequencing and identifying new variants and their transmissibility and evolution.

The second topic is forecasting COVID-19 dynamics at the district/state level. Forecasting COVID-19 dynamics has been challenging everywhere; in India it has been even more challenging for a number of reasons including noisy data, undercounting of the deceased, lack of information on compliance of NPIs implemented, etc. This project will leverage ongoing work by team members on this topic to develop innovative COVID-19 forecasting methods for the Indian context. It will explore the use of multiple data sources to combat the inconsistencies and incorporate publicly available forecasts from other modeling teams to obtain robust ensembled forecasts.

The third topic is vaccine prioritization, allocation, and distribution. This project will develop models and analytical tools to study a range of questions related to vaccine prioritization, allocation and distribution. The significant second surge has highlighted widespread susceptibility in early 2021, due either to waning immunity and/or limited spread of the first wave. With the possibility of novel variants due to uncontrolled spread, and emerging possibilities in vaccine development, an expedited, effective, and equitable vaccine campaign remains the most important pathway to controlling COVID-19 in India and elsewhere. 

The project will lead to new methods that combine multi-scale simulations with recent techniques in AI and machine learning to obtain implementable solutions to the problems above. The methods will also be generalizable -- the goal is to develop the needed technical capability to respond to future pandemics. This innovative partnership between academic institutions in the US and India will form the basis of future joint collaborations on this important topical area of global importance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the RAPID: Modeling and Analytics for COVID-19 Outbreak Response in India: A multi-institutional, US-India joint collaborative effort project was to study three broad problems that affect evidence-based public health decision making in the US and India, ideally moving closer to solutions that could be implemented globally. 

Integrated active genomic biosurveillance

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the interplay between viral mutations, human behavior, vaccines, and public policies. An integral element of pandemic management is genomic biosurveillance: collecting samples and sequences related to viruses across space and time, and combining this information to assess the distribution and impact of viral strains. This is challenging as it depends on the mutation rate, selection pressures, and global data collection.

To better understand the intrinsic relationship between disease dynamics and genomic composition and the impact of aggregated data surveillance systems, we employed an abductive framework for smart surveillance and sensing. The effects of the feedback loop between disease dynamics, variant emergence, and intervention timing and strength were highlighted via numerical simulations.

Our results suggest the time required to detect a novel variant heavily depends on cross-infection and on emergence time. Particularly, we found that if the novel variant emerges relatively early with regards to the prime variant, cross-infection does not impact the detection time. Finally, we found there is an optimal response scenario minimizing the second variant peak, defined by the detection time and cross-infection of the novel variant. 

Vaccine prioritization, allocation, and distribution 

Our second goal was to develop models and analytical tools to study a range of questions related to vaccine prioritization, allocation, and distribution. We incorporated serosurveys and other on-the-ground datasets using various metrics to evaluate the benefits of proposed vaccine prioritization strategies across districts in Karnataka, India. In our analysis we considered waning immunity, immune escape, clinical and logistical aspects of managing a multi-dose multi-vaccine campaign, and socio-behavioral aspects like NPI compliance and vaccine acceptance. 

Given the limited supply of vaccines, the eligibility of the entire adult population for vaccination, and heterogeneous spread of COVID-19 across Indian districts, a study of vaccination allocation policies across districts was needed at the time of initial vaccine roll-out. We focused our analysis on the state of Karnataka which has had spread dynamics similar to India. In addition, Karnataka conducted extensive serosurveys to understand the spread of infection in the population which we incorporated when tuning our model. There are multiple possible criteria for vaccine allocation across districts, including population, seroprevalence, or case-incidence rates, and assessing the effectiveness of these strategies was complicated due to many factors. To account for these factors and assess the overall impact of the vaccination strategies, we employed a modeling study using a spatially explicit, age-stratified epidemiological model. The three vaccination strategies we considered were (i) allocation proportional to the district populations, (ii) allocation inversely proportional to the seroprevalence estimates, and (iii) allocation in proportion to the case-incidence rates during a reference period. 

The results suggest that the focus should be on the easy-to-implement allocation scheme based on population. Our immunity waning model predicted the possibility of a subsequent resurgence even under relatively strong NPIs. Also, importantly, given a per-day vaccination capacity, our results suggest the level of NPIs needed for the healthcare infrastructure to handle a surge.

Forecasting COVID-19 dynamics

The UVA team has been participating in the CDC- and ECDC-initiated COVID-19 ForecastHub since their inception in 2020. The ensemble model forecasts have on most occasions been more accurate than independent models. We wanted to leverage this fact and build a consortium similar to the US and EU ForecastHubs. Using the experience gained through participation in the ForecastHub consortium, the UVA team partnered with the IISc team in India to set up a ForecastHub. Our task was to help the Indian team set up the pipeline for the ForecastHub, provide visualization tools, and then hand over the weekly operations of the Hub to the Indian team. The ensemble model, which is a median of the forecasts from the individual models, is run and updated on the dashboard each week to show the 1?4 week ahead forecasts of individual and ensemble models. 

Five teams (one from the US, four from India) participated in the forecasting efforts with some of the teams providing multiple models. Each week, the participating teams were required to provide 1-4 week ahead forecasts of the incident cases. The forecasts from the individual models were then aggregated using a median ensemble. Since its inception in 2021, teams have submitted over 75 weeks of forecasts, and we have been able to achieve standardization of forecast data through this platform. Previously, forecasts from individual teams were available on their respective websites. The dashboard that the UVA team helped build has brought all the forecasts under one website and helped display the heterogeneity in forecasts.


 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Madhav V Marathe
